questions.text: On performing polysomnography in a patient, the waves of EOG, EEG, and EMG, from above downwards, are seen below. Which stage of sleep do the marked areas represent? EOG: Electrooculography EEG: Electroencephalography EMG: Electromyography

options.label: C
options.text: NREM II sleep NREM III sleep

questions.explanation:
REM findings on EEG, EOG, EMG

 

EEG (Electroencephalogram)

• EEG activity is increased similar to the awake state (beta activity) along with the return of alpha activity

• The typical appearance of these waves is known as Sawtooth waves or Sawtooth appearance.

• Paradoxical sleep: Even though the person is sleeping, the EEG shows activity similar to that of the awake state.

• PGO (Ponto Geniculo Occipital) spikes are also seen - Large phasic potentials that originate from Pons (the cholinergic neurons) and go towards the lateral geniculate body and to the occipital spikes.

EOG (Electrooculogram)

Rapid eye movements are seen

EMG (Electromyogram)

• Tonic atonia (as if the muscle is in paralysis) with phasic twitches

• It means there is a near-complete loss of muscle tone, preventing movement during vivid dreaming.

 

Stage

EEG

EOG

EMG

Awake (Stage W)

Alpha waves (8-13 Hz) with eyes closed

Eye movements and blinks present

Slow eye movements

Tonic activity decreases

(Option C)

Sleep spindles (12-14 Hz), K complexes (sharp negative followed by positive waves)

None

Very low tonic activity

N3 Stage (Deep Sleep)

(Option D)

None

questions.text: Match the following: Kleptomania Intense desire to drink alcoholic drinks 2. Pyromania B. Intense desire to mutilate 3. Mutilomania C. Intense desire to steal items of trivial value 4. Dipsomania D. Intense desire to burn things
questions.explanation:
Kleptomania
  • It is the intense desire to steal items of trivial value
  • It is managed by insight-oriented psychotherapy, psychoanalysis, CBT, and behavioural therapies (e.g., systematic desensitization).
  • Medications: SSRIs, tricyclic antidepressants, lithium, naltrexone.

Pyromania
  • It is the intense desire to burn things
  • Treatment is challenging; CBT is the most promising approach,and family therapy is essential for youth.
  • Limited medication options; potential benefits from SSRIs, lithium, and naltrexone.

Mutilomania

It is the intense desire to mutilate

Dipsomania

It is the intense desire to drink alcoholic drinks

Types of impulses

Kleptomania

Compulsive stealing

Dipsomania

Compulsive drinking of alcohol

Pyromania

Urge to set fires

Mutilomania

Intense desire to mutilate

Oniomania

Compulsive shopping

Trichotillomania

Compulsive hair-pulling

Suicidal Impulse

The urge to commit suicide, often triggered by intoxication

Homicidal Impulse

Urge to commit homicide, linked to chronic intoxication

Schwartz formula

 

GFR (mL/min/1.73 m²) = (k x height (cm)) / Serum creatinine (mg/dL)

Age Group

GFR (mL/min/1.73 m²)

Inference

Birth (Full-term Infants)

15-20

GFR is low at birth; renal function is still maturing.

Birth (Preterm Infants)

10-15

Lower GFR compared to full-term infants due to underdeveloped kidneys.

2 Weeks

35-45

Rapid increase in GFR as renal function starts maturing.

2 Months

75-80

Continued rapid increase, nearing levels seen in older infants.

Childhood (up to 2 years)

Approaches 80-120 (comparable to adults after correction for body size)

Renal function continues to improve, reaching near-adult GFR levels by age two when corrected for body surface area.

questions.text: A child presents with acute exacerbation of asthma. Which of the following would you do? Chest X-ray Oxygen administration Salbutamol nebulization three times in 60 minutes Administration of oral corticosteroids
questions.explanation:
Management of Acute Asthma attacks

Immediate Treatment
  • Oxygen Therapy (2): Administer via mask or nasal cannula to maintain SpO2 > 92%.
  • Inhaled SABAs (3):
    • Albuterol: 2.5 mg/3 mL nebulized every 20 mins for 3 doses;
    • Levalbuterol: 1.25 mg/0.5 mL up to 3 doses every 20 mins.
  • Systemic Corticosteroids (4):
    • Prednisone: 1-2 mg/kg/day orally (max 60 mg/day);
    • Methylprednisolone: 1-2 mg/kg IV, then oral dosing.

Adjunctive Treatments
  • Inhaled Anticholinergics, Ipratropium Bromide: 0.5 mg nebulized every 6-8 hours as needed.
  • Intravenous Magnesium Sulfate: 25-75 mg/kg IV over 20 minutes (max 2 grams).

Escalation of Care
  • Continuous Nebulization:
    • Albuterol: 10-15 mg/hour via nebulizer.
  • Parenteral β-Agonists:
    • Terbutaline: 2-10 µg/kg IV loading dose followed by 0.1-0.4 microgram/kg/min titrate in 0.1-0.2 µg/kg/min increments every 30 min
    • Epinephrine: 0.01 mg/kg SC or IM, repeat every 15-30 min if needed.

Monitoring & Management
  • Close Monitoring:
    • Continuous monitoring of vital signs, oxygen saturation, and clinical response. Assess improvement in symptoms, PEF, and lung function.
  • Risk Assessment for Discharge:
    • Criteria: Sustained improvement, PEF > 70% predicted, oxygen saturation > 92% on room air. Ensure home capability for medication administration.

Common between 6-60 months, benign, and does not require extensive workup.

questions.text: Identify the given plant based on its features
questions.explanation:
Argemone Mexicana (Prickly Poppy)

Toxic Parts

Entire plant; seeds resemble mustard seeds but are darker with minute projections.

Toxic Oil

Argemone oil (katkar oil) causes epidemic dropsy.

Active Principles

Plant Alkaloids: Berberine, Protopine.

Oil Alkaloids: Sanguinarine, Dihydrosanguinarine. (Cause abnormal blood vessel permeability.)

General Symptoms

Gradual onset with appetite loss, diarrhea, leg edema, and generalized anasarca.

System-Specific Signs

Heart: Myocardial damage, heart dilatation.

CVS: Hypotension, breathlessness, feeble pulse.

Hepatic: Enlarged, tender liver.

PNS: Tingling, hyperesthesia, calf muscle tenderness, reduced or absent jerks.

Ocular: Dim vision due to increased intraocular pressure.

Skin: Bluish mottling from peripheral vessel dilation.

Fatal Outcome

Severe heart damage.

Treatment

Balanced diet, decontamination, cessation of oil consumption, diuretics, corticosteroids, and supportive care.

Medico-Legal Aspects

Argemone oil is commonly used to adulterate mustard or other edible oils.

During a routine eye examination, a patient's visual acuity was evaluated using Snellen's chart, and it was determined to be 6/6. What is the smallest angle at which this patient can differentiate two separate points or objects?
questions.explanation:
Snellen’s chart
  • Measures visual acuity by assessing the eye's ability to distinguish details or separate points.
  • Rows of decreasing-sized letters fit within squares. Each letter subtends an angle of 5 minutes, and the lines forming letters subtend 1 minute of arc.
 

Visual Acuity Notation
  • Snellen Fraction: Denoted as a fraction, with the numerator being 6 meters and the denominator indicating the distance at which normal vision reads the same letter (e.g., 6/18 means the patient reads at 6 meters what normal vision reads at 18 meters).
  • Metric/Imperial: 6/6 = 20/20 vision.
  • Decimal Acuity: 6/6 equals 1.0 decimal acuity.

Testing Procedure

The patient is positioned 6 meters from the chart, and each eye is tested individually, starting with the right eye. The patient reads the smallest visible letter.

Limitations
  • Refractive Errors: Primarily measures uncorrected vision. Pinhole tests help detect refractive errors that can be corrected with lenses.
  • Subjectivity: Dependent on patient literacy, language, and cognitive ability.
  • Scope: Assesses only visual acuity, not contrast sensitivity, color vision, or peripheral vision.

Which investigation is not necessary for the following condition?
questions.explanation:
Achalasia Cardia

Definition

Progressive degeneration of ganglion cells in the oesophagal wall. This leads to a loss of peristalsis in the lower oesophagus and failure of the lower oesophagal sphincter (LES) to relax during swallowing.

Clinical Features
  • Dysphagia: May initially affect liquids more than solids.
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Chest Pain
  • Weight Loss

Investigations

Esophageal Manometry (Option C ruled out)

  • Gold Standard: This is the definitive diagnostic test for achalasia. It measures the pressure and pattern of muscle contractions in the oesophagus.
  • Elevated resting LES pressure (typically > 45 mmHg).
  • Incomplete LES relaxation.
  • Absence of peristalsis in the esophageal body.
  • Periodic contractions with normal amplitude or high amplitude contractions (type I and II achalasia).

Barium Swallow (Esophagram) (Option A ruled out)

  • Dilated esophagus with a narrowing at the LES (Bird beak appearance).

Endoscopy (Option B ruled out)

  • Normal mucosa but may show dilated esophagus with possible food debris; it is important to rule out other causes of dysphagia, such as tumours.

Management

Pharmacological Treatments

  • Calcium Channel Blockers (reduce LES pressure)
  • Nitrates (relax the LES)
  • 5'-Phosphodiesterase Inhibitors (increase cyclic GMP to lower LES pressure)
  • Botulinum Toxin (Botox) Injections (temporarily paralyse LES muscles).

Non-Surgical Interventions

  • Bougie/Balloon Dilatation (ruptures LES muscle fibres to reduce pressure).

Surgical Treatments

  • Laparoscopic Heller's Cardiomyotomy (Most common)
    • The incision in the LES muscle to reduce pressure.
    • It is often combined with a fundoplication.
  • Partial Fundoplication
    • Prevents reflux; options include Dor or Toupet fundoplication.
  • Esophagectomy
    • Surgical removal of the esophagus (severe cases).

Endoscopic Treatments

  • Per-Oral Endoscopic Myotomy (POEM): A newer Minimally invasive procedure involving dissection of LES muscle fibres.

A 34-year-old woman was brought to the AIIMS emergency following a road traffic accident. She was hemodynamically stable, and her GCS score was 3. She was intubated and sent for non-contrast C,T which was found to be normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI)

A form of primary brain injury caused by widespread damage to axons due to rotational acceleration and deceleration forces, often associated with high-energy trauma.

Cause
  • Rotational forces: High-energy accidents involving rapid acceleration and deceleration (e.g., motor vehicle collisions).
  • Trauma: Blunt force impacts that cause the brain to rotate within the skull.

Clinical Features
  • Impaired arousal: Often presents as coma or reduced consciousness due to damage in critical brain areas (e.g., pontine reticular activating system, bilateral thalami).
  • Neurological deficits: Poor neurological examination despite the absence of obvious radiographic global brain injury.
  • Irreversible consequences: DAI is often associated with severe and lasting neurological impairment.

Investigations
  • CT scan: May show hemorrhagic foci in the corpus callosum and dorsolateral rostral brainstem in severe cases.
  • MRI:
    • More sensitive than CT.
    • It shows small haemorrhages and diffuse axonal injury, particularly in patients who fail to improve neurologically.
  • Postmortem examination: Confirms the diagnosis with axonal disruption and formation of axon balls.

Prognosis

Very poor due to high risk of severe disability or death due to extensive brain damage.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with a pelvic fracture following blunt abdominal trauma. No blood is seen at the meatus. Catheterisation does not produce significant urine output. The radiological image is given below. What is the next step in management?

options.label: D
options.text: Pelvic packing along with B/L percutaneous nephrostomy

questions.explanation:
Intraperitoneal Bladder Rupture

Involves a tear or injury to the peritoneum over the bladder, and urine leaks into the peritoneal cavity in males.

Causes

Often occurs in a fully distended bladder, usually due to trauma or injury

Clinical Features
  • Sudden, severe pain in the suprapubic region.
  • Signs of shock and syncope.
  • Diffuse abdominal pain with later features of peritonitis.
  • Abdominal distension.
  • Haematuria
  • Absence of desire to urinate

Diagnosis
  • Plain X-ray: It may show a ground glass appearance.
  • Peritoneal Tap: Used to collect urine from the abdominal cavity.
  • Cystography: Iodine dye is injected via a catheter to visualise bladder tears and the dye entry into the peritoneal cavity. The contrast outlines the bowel loops.
  • Ultrasound: To assess other abdominal injuries.

Treatment
  • Emergency Laparotomy is required. (Option C).
  • Bladder tear is sutured with polylactic acid (vicryl) in two layers.
  • Peritoneal wash to clean out the peritoneal cavity.
  • Separate drainage for prevesical space and peritoneal cavity.
  • Administration of specific antibiotics to prevent sepsis.
  • Catheterisation:
    • Malecot’s catheter is placed suprapubically.
    • Foley's catheter passed urethrally.

Complications
  • Cystitis /and pyelonephritis.
  • Peritonitis.
  • Pelvic abscess.
  • Fistula formation (vesicovaginal or rectovesical).
  • Paralytic ileus.
  • Hemorrhage.

Extra Peritoneal bladder rupture

Intra Peritoneal bladder rupture
  • Caused by pelvic fractures and rapid deceleration.
  • Leakage into thighs, perineum, penis, anterior abdominal wall.
  • Commonly associated with pelvic fractures.
  • Pelvic molar tooth sign: Contrast media leaking from the bladder and accumulating in the preperitoneal space, creating a molar tooth-shaped appearance on CT cystography after extraperitoneal bladder rupture.
  • Occurs at the bladder dome, above the peritoneal reflection.
  • Caused by a direct blow to a distended bladder.
  • Urine leakage into the abdomen causes metabolic derangements.

questions.text: Which of the following would be the most commonly encountered ectopic tissue in Meckel’s diverticulum?
questions.explanation:
Meckel's Diverticulum

Clinical features
  • Most common ectopic mucosa in Meckel’s diverticulum is Gastric > Pancreatic > Colonic (Option A) (Option B, C ruled out)
  • The most common symptom in children is gastrointestinal bleeding.
  • Ulcers are formed in the surrounding area due to acid secreted from the ectopic gastric mucosa in Meckel’s diverticulum, which causes bleeding.
  • The most common symptom in adults is abdominal pain.
  • Complications: Volvulus, intestinal obstruction, intussusceptions, diverticulitis and perforation.

Investigations
  • 99mTc-pertechnetate scan: Absorbed by the ectopic gastric mucosa, allowing for visualisation.
  • Plain abdominal radiography, CT abdomen, and ultrasonography are seldom useful.
  • Endoscopy: Helpful in false-negative cases, but not the investigation of choice.

Management

  • Healthy base (no induration or ulceration): Diverculectomy (excision of the diverticulum only) + anastomosis.
  • Unhealthy base (ulceration, presence of gastric mucosa): Resection of the small bowel with the diverticulum + anastomosis.
  • Incidentally detected during an elective surgery: Diverculectomy.

questions.text: What is true about gall bladder carcinoma?

options.label: A
options.text: Palpable abdominal lump is the earliest sign

options.label: C
options.text: Gallstones and gallbladder cancer are easily distinguished clinically

options.label: D
options.text: Median survival is less than 6 months

questions.correct_answer: D. Median survival is less than 6 months
questions.explanation:
Gallbladder Cancer

Etiology

  • Gallstones
  • Choledochal cyst
  • Anomalous pancreaticobiliary duct junction
  • Cholesterosis of the gallbladder
  • Gallbladder polyps
  • Porcelain gallbladder
  • Infections and inflammatory conditions
    • Chronic typhoid carriers
    • Inflammatory bowel disease
    • Hepatitis B and hepatitis C virus infections
  • Other factors:
    • Polypoid lesions (GB polyp)
    • Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis
    • Nitrosamines
    • Carcinogens

Clinical features

  • Often indistinguishable from benign gallbladder diseases (Option C ruled out)
  • Symptoms include:
    • Biliary colic
    • Cholecystitis (especially in older individuals)
    • Jaundice (late-stage) (Option B ruled out)
    • Loss of appetite (late-stage)
    • Palpable mass (late-stage) (Option A ruled out)

Laboratory Findings
  • Non-specific indicators:
    • Anemia
    • Leukocytosis
    • Slight increase in transaminases
  • Tumor markers:
    • Elevated CA19-9
    • Elevated carcinoembryonic antigen (in ~80% of patients)

Diagnostic Imaging
  • Ultrasonography (USG): Initial diagnosis
  • CT Scans: Thorax, abdomen, and pelvis for confirmation and staging
  • MRI/MRCP: For accurate preoperative staging
  • PET Scans: To identify metastatic disease

Staging and Biopsy
  • Preoperative Staging: Crucial to assess local disease extent and rule out distant metastases
  • Percutaneous Biopsy: Guided by radiological imaging for unresectable tumours
  • Laparoscopic Examination: Detects peritoneal or liver metastases that preclude surgery

Management
  • Early disease:
    • For disease confined to the mucosa, if there is negative cystic duct margin and no recurrence on imaging- No further treatment
  • For transmural disease- Radical en bloc resection of gallbladder fossa, liver wedge, and regional lymph nodes.
  • Advanced Cancer:
    • Non-operative palliative care.
    • Endoscopic/percutaneous methods to relieve obstructive jaundice.
  • Adenocarcinoma:
    • Early-stage limited to mucosa:
  • No additional treatment is required if imaging shows no recurrence.
  • Beyond mucosa:
    • Extensive surgery involving gallbladder fossa, a portion of the liver, and nearby lymph nodes.

What should be the subsequent step in managing a 32-year-old male patient who comes to the surgical emergency department with a 2-day history of peptic ulcer disease, experiencing abdominal pain, bloating, and difficulty passing stools? IV fluids CECT abdomen Exploratory laparotomy Upper GI endoscopy Below is the provided X-ray film image
questions.explanation:
Duodenal ulcer perforation
  • Common with anterior duodenal ulcers.
  • Presents with an acute abdomen with sudden-onset, severe epigastric pain, rebound tenderness, and air under the diaphragm in the radiograph. (Option B)
  • Management:
    • Non-surgical:
      • Nil per-oral
      • IV antibiotics and PPIs
    • Surgical:
      • Initial empirical antibiotic treatment.
      • The perforation is approached by a small upper midline incision
      • Perforations <1cm are closed primarily and buttressed with a well-vascularized omentum
      • Larger perforations & with fibrotic edges: Modified Graham's Repair or Omental Patch Repair.
      • The vascularized pedicle of the greater omentum is patched over the defect.

Bleeding duodenal ulcer
  • A posterior duodenal ulcer is the one that usually bleeds.
  • It is due to the involvement of the gastroduodenal artery.
  • This leads to hematemesis, melena or both i.e., an upper GI bleed.
  • Bleeding is commonly associated with intake of NSAIDs.
  • Management:
    • Endoscopic: Done to find the bleeding source and manage bleeds endoscopically. Injection, thermal coagulation, plasma argon coagulation, mechanical clips, and fibrin glue are the methods used. (with or without adrenaline injection).
    • Angiographic management: If endoscopic management fails.
    • Surgical management:
      • Exposure to the ulcer and ligation of the duodenum are the principles here.
      • Duodenotomy
      • Ligation of the bleeding vessel with truncal vagotomy with pyloroplasty

Gastric Outlet Obstruction (GOO)
  • Acute inflammation of the duodenum or pylorus leads to mechanical obstruction with a functional gastric outlet obstruction.
  • Presents with nausea, early satiety, vomiting, loss of weight, and anorexia.

Hourglass deformity

It is seen in chronic gastric ulcers with scarring and fibrosis.

Pyloric stenosis

It is seen in cases of chronic ulcers, which lead to stricture and constriction of the pylorus.

questions.text: Identify the correct statement regarding gastric carcinoma: It is mostly hereditary E-cadherin adhesion defect is seen in diffuse types of gastric CA. Wnt signaling pathway defect is seen in intestinal-type gastric CA. Depth of cancer has no role in prognosis.
questions.explanation:
Category

Risk factors

Diet

High-salt foods (e.g., salted and smoked meats), low intake of fruits and vegetables

N-nitroso compounds are formed from nitrates in high-salt and smoked foods, Similar to tobacco smoke

Lifestyle habits

Smoking, alcohol, poor food preparation (smoked, salted), lack of refrigeration, contaminated drinking water, low socioeconomic status

Infectious Causes

H- pylori infection: M/c infectious cause of gastric cancer.

Mechanism: Chronic inflammation leading to atrophic gastritis, intestinal metaplasia, dysplasia, and carcinoma

Polyps
  • Adenomatous polyps (risk of malignancy)
  • In multiple polyps, the largest one is excised, and biopsy from others is taken.

Hereditary factors
  • E-cadherin (CDH1) gene mutation (hereditary diffuse gastric cancer) (Statement B)
  • Hereditary cancer syndromes
  • Li- Fraumeni syndrome

Medications

Proton pump inhibitors (long-term use creates low-acid environment achlorhydria; Risk for H. pylori colonisation)

Other risk factors

Gastric ulcers, pernicious anaemia (achlorhydria), obesity, Epstein-Barr virus, prior abdominal irradiation (for testicular cancer or Hodgkin’s lymphoma), prior gastric surgery, male sex

questions.text: An old lady sustained a fall and developed a headache and neurological symptoms a few days later. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Subdural Hematoma (SDH)

Causes

Tearing of bridging veins, often due to blunt trauma / acceleration-deceleration injuries.

Mechanism

  
  • High-energy injury: Rupture of cortical surface vessels.
  • Low-energy injury: Venous bleeding, common in older adults on anticoagulants.

Clinical Presentation
  • Variable presentation depending on injury severity and timing.
  • Signs of raised intracranial pressure: Headache, reduced consciousness, focal neurological deficits.

CT Appearance

Diffuse concave hyperdense (acute), isodense (subacute), or hypodense (chronic) lesions over the brain surface, often crossing suture lines.

Management

Depends on size, location, and clinical status:

1. Large or worsening hematomas: Urgent evacuation by craniotomy or craniectomy.

2. Smaller, stable bleeds: Conservative management initially, with surgery if needed.

Marjolin ulcer over the dorsum of foot measuring 3cm x 2cm

Wedge biopsy (removing a small wedge-shaped tissue sample from the nodule) is commonly performed on a Marjolin ulcer (a malignant transformation in a chronic non-healing wound).

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple stab injuries to the chest. On examination, there is reduced chest movement on the right side and tracheal deviation to the left side. Additionally, the neck veins are distended. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Tension Pneumothorax

It is a life-threatening condition where air accumulates in the pleural cavity under pressure, causing lung collapse on the affected side, mediastinal shift, and severe impairment of cardiovascular function.

Pathology
  • It occurs when air enters the pleural cavity through a "one-way valve" mechanism, leading to lung collapse and mediastinal shift towards the opposite side.
  • ↑Pleural pressure→ Opposite lung compression→ ↓venous return→ ↓cardiac output and potentially sudden death.

Aetiology
  • Penetrating chest trauma.
  • Blunt chest trauma with parenchymal lung injury.
  • Iatrogenic lung injury (e.g., central venous catheterisation) and mechanical positive-pressure ventilation.

Clinical Features
  • Restlessness, tachypnea, dyspnea, tachycardia, and chest pain.
  • Distended neck veins, hyper-resonance, and decreased or absent breath sound on the affected side.
  • Late findings may include tracheal deviation and cyanosis.
  • Hypotension and severe mediastinal/tracheal shift are also common.

Management
  • Needle Thoracocentesis: Immediate decompression with a large-bore needle in the 2nd intercostal space at the midclavicular line, or the "safe triangle".
  • Followed by intercostal chest tube (ICT) placement in the 5th intercostal space in the anterior axillary line.
  • Provide oxygen, analgesics, antibiotics, and ventilator support if necessary.

questions.text: Which of the following is the initial treatment of choice for managing the condition in a female patient who comes to the hospital with palpitations, having stable vital signs and an ECG showing the following?
questions.explanation:
Acute termination:
  • Vagal maneuvers (e.g., Valsalva, carotid sinus massage)
  • If vagal maneuvers fail, IV adenosine is the first-line pharmacological treatment: 6 mg - 12mg fast iv push.
  • Alternative drugs: verapamil, diltiazem, or beta-blockers
  • Synchronized cardioversion for hemodynamically unstable patients

Long-term management:
  • Catheter ablation: Often curative, especially for AVNRT and AVRT
  • Pharmacological therapy:
    • Beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers for prevention
    • Class IC or III antiarrhythmic drugs in selected cases
  • Patient education on performing vagal maneuvers

Lifestyle modifications
  • Avoid triggers (e.g., caffeine, alcohol, stress)
  • Regular exercise
  • Adequate sleep

All of the following are theories of causation of preeclampsia except:

options.label: A
options.text: Prostaglandins play an important role; Thromboxane A2 decreases; Prostaglandin: Thromboxane ratio increases in preeclampsia

options.label: B

options.label: C

questions.correct_answer: A. Prostaglandins play an important role; Thromboxane A2 decreases; Prostaglandin: Thromboxane ratio increases in preeclampsia
questions.explanation:
Abnormal Trophoblastic Invasion

Incomplete remodeling of spiral arteries → Narrow, high-resistance vessels → Reduced placental perfusion → Hypoxia.

Endothelial Dysfunction

sFlt-1 and endoglin release → Inhibition of VEGF and PIGF → Reduced NO production → Vasoconstriction, increased vascular permeability (proteinuria, edema). (Option B ruled out)

Imbalance in Angiogenic Factors

Increased sFlt-1, decreased VEGF and PIGF → Impaired vascular repair and angiogenesis → Endothelial injury. (Option D ruled out)

Oxidative Stress and Inflammation

Hypoxia-reoxygenation injury → ROS and pro-inflammatory cytokines → Endothelial damage, pro-thrombotic state.

Vasoconstriction and Platelet Aggregation

Decreased PGI2 (vasodilator) and increased TXA2 (vasoconstrictor) → Systemic vasoconstriction, microvascular thrombosis.

Multi-Organ Ischemia and Damage

Vasoconstriction and endothelial dysfunction → Reduced blood flow to:

  • Kidneys: Proteinuria (glomerular endotheliosis).
  • Liver: Hepatic ischemia, HELLP syndrome.
  • Brain: Cerebral edema, seizures (eclampsia).
  • Placenta: Fetal growth restriction, abruption. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding MgSO4 is false?

options.label: A
options.text: MgSO4 causes uterine relaxation, but is dose-dependent

options.label: B
options.text: MgSO4 is continued up to 24 hours after delivery or last attack of seizure

options.label: C
options.text: It has an inhibitory effect on the cerebral cortex, thereby preventing seizures and lowering the BP

options.label: D
options.text: In renal failure, MgSO4 loading dose can be given, but maintenance dose should be adjusted based on renal function

questions.correct_answer: C. It has an inhibitory effect on the cerebral cortex, thereby preventing seizures and lowering the BP
questions.explanation:
MOA
  • NMDA Receptor Blockade
  • Calcium Channel Blockade: reduces calcium influx into neurons.
  • Vasodilation: Improves cerebral blood flow and reduces cerebral edema, dilates uterine arteries, increases endothelial prostacyclin production and inhibits platelet activation.

Uses
  • Prevent seizures in severe preeclampsia and eclampsia.
  • Prevent recurrent seizures in eclampsia.
  • Tocolytic effect (delaying preterm labor)
  • Neuroprotective: Protects the preterm baby's brain from damage by reducing the risk of cerebral palsy

Therapeutic Range

To control fits the optimum serum magnesium is 4.8–8.4 mg/dL (4–7 mEq/L). Deep tendon reflex loss at 9 mg/dL (>7 mEq/L).

C/I

Myasthenia gravis, hypocalcemia, moderate-to-severe renal failure, cardiac ischemia, heart block, myocarditis.

Administration and Dosage

Administer: Intravenously or intramuscularly.

  • Loading dose: 4–6 g IV over 20–30 minutes. (Zuspan or Sibai regimen)
  • Maintenance: 1–2 g/hour IV. Monitor urine output and reflexes.

Dosage Adjustment

Adjust for renal dysfunction.

Regimen

Loading Dose

Maintenance Dose

Pritchard

(IV and IM)
  • Administer 4 g IV over 3-5 mins (20 mL of 20% MgSO4 solution)
  • Follow with 10 g of 50% MgSO4 solution: 5 g (10 mL of 50% solution) in each buttock as deep IM injection with 1 mL of 2% lidocaine in the same syringe.
  • 5g IM with 1 mL of 2% lidocaine in alternate buttocks every 4 hours; continue for 24 hours after birth or last convulsion

Zuspan

(IV only)
  • Administer 4-6 g IV over 15- 20 mins (20 mL of 20% magnesium sulfate solution).
  • If convulsions recur after 15 mins, give 2g IV (10 mL of 20% MgSO4 solution) over 5 mins.
  • 1-2 g IV infusion per hour (5 mL of 20% solution); continue for 24 hours after childbirth or last convulsion

Serum Magnesium Level

Effect

5–9 mg/dL

9 mg/dL

Loss of patellar reflexes

12 mg/dL

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady had an uneventful vaginal delivery. On postpartum day 1, she presented with postpartum hemorrhage and complains of visual changes and severe headache. A few hours after the complaint, she is found to be in an unresponsive state and is intubated and put on ventilation. On further examination, she has a BP of 60/40 mmHg and tachycardia, and blood sugar is 48 mg/dL. Hematocrit and WBC count was normal. Which of the following drugs would help reverse this state?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Postpartum hypopituitarism caused by ischemic necrosis of the pituitary gland following severe postpartum hemorrhage.

Symptoms

• Failure to lactate

• Hypotension

• Hypoglycemia

• fatigue

• amenorrhea

• Hypothyroidism

• adrenal insufficiency

• decreased libido

• weight gain

• cold intolerance

Diagnosis

• Clinical history of severe postpartum hemorrhage.

• Hormonal evaluation: Low levels of pituitary hormones (prolactin, TSH, ACTH, LH, FSH, growth hormone).

• MRI: Empty sella or reduced pituitary size.

 

Treatment

Lifelong hormone replacement therapy (glucocorticoids, levothyroxine, estrogen-progesterone, growth hormone if needed)

questions.text: What is the age group distribution for vulval cancer?
questions.explanation:
Age Group

Most common in elderly women, especially in the 6th and 7th decades, (50-70 years age group)

Risk Factors

HPV infections, HSV infections, smoking, chronic immunosuppression, chronic inflammatory conditions (e.g., lichen sclerosis).

Histological Type

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common type.

Common Sites
  • Labia majora: Most common site (60%).
  • Clitoris: Second most common site (15%).

Presentation
  • Exophytic (outward-growing) growth.
  • Ulcerative lesions.

Symptoms
  • Pruritus (most common), often associated with an itch-scratch cycle.
  • Swelling, lump, or ulcer.
  • Cancer cachexia (weight loss and muscle wasting).
  • Cancer pain (late symptom).

Spread
  • Primarily through the lymphatic system.
  • Vulvar lymphatics cross midline, especially within 2 cm of the midline.
  • Commonly involved lymph nodes: Inguinofemoral.
  • Lymph node involvement significantly impacts prognosis.

Investigations
  • Excisional biopsy: Preferred for lesions < 1 cm, for histological assessment of invasion depth.
  • Incisional biopsy: For lesions ≥ 1 cm.
  • Wedge biopsy, Keyes punch biopsy, and sentinel lymph node biopsy (to assess inguinofemoral node involvement).

Treatment
  • Vulvectomy: Partial or total, depending on the disease stage.
  • Inguinal lymph node dissection: To evaluate disease spread.
  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy: Determines stage and prognosis.

questions.text: The given image depicts:

options.label: C
options.text: Both the succenturiate lobe and velamentous insertion of the cord

questions.correct_answer: C. Both the succenturiate lobe and velamentous insertion of the cord
questions.explanation:
Condition

Description

Succenturiate placenta

• Extra lobes form separate from the main placental body within the membranes, connected to it by fetal vessels and membranes.

• It occurs only in 5 % of placentas

Bilobed Placenta

Placenta with two roughly equal lobes separated by a membrane.

Placenta accreta spectrum

• Occurs when the placenta is abnormally adherent to the uterine wall after childbirth.

• The spectrum has 3 conditions: 

◦ Accreta

◦ Increta

◦ Percreta

• It occurs in 1 out of 2500 pregnancies

Ring-shaped Placenta

An annularly shaped placenta, often resembling a horseshoe due to partial atrophy, is rare.

Placenta Membranacea

A rare condition where chorionic villi cover fetal membranes either partially or completely, occupying the periphery of the chorion.

Circumvallate Placenta

Placenta with raised edges composed of chorion, amnion, and fibrin deposits are associated with poor pregnancy outcomes.

Circummarginate Placenta

 

Similar to the circumvallate placenta but with a flat transition from membranous to villous chorion.

 

Battledore Placenta

An umbilical cord is inserted at or near the placental margin rather than in the centre.

It is associated with pregnancy complications like preterm labour and fetal distress.

Placenta spuria

Unequal placenta not connected by vessel

The following cost-effective investigations are routinely recommended in the screening of antenatal mothers, except:
questions.explanation:
Trimester

Investigations

First Trimester
  • Hemoglobin and hematocrit
  • Blood grouping and Rh typing
  • Blood glucose testing
  • VDRL testing
  • Midstream urine analysis (protein, sugar, nitrites)
  • Serology for rubella, hepatitis B, and HIV
  • Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (optional)
  • Ultrasound (Dating Scan): Confirms gestational age, fetal viability, and number of fetuses
  • Pap smear (if not done within the last year)

Second Trimester
  • Ultrasound (Anomaly Scan, 18–20 weeks): Assesses fetal anatomy, structural abnormalities, amniotic fluid index, and placental location
  • Oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT, 24–28 weeks)
  • Repeat urine analysis
  • Quadruple marker screening (optional)
  • Antibody screening (for Rh-negative mothers)
  • Ultrasound (Fetal Echocardiography, if indicated): Detailed evaluation of fetal heart for congenital anomalies

Third Trimester
  • Repeat hemoglobin and hematocrit
  • Repeat serology for syphilis, HIV, and hepatitis B
  • Vaginal and rectal swab for Group B Streptococcus (GBS) testing (35–37 weeks)
  • Ultrasound (Growth Scan): Monitors fetal growth, amniotic fluid levels, and placental function
  • Non-stress test (NST) or biophysical profile (BPP, if indicated)
  • Coagulation profile (if indicated)
  • Ultrasound (Doppler Scan, if indicated): Evaluates placental and fetal blood flow in conditions like IUGR or preeclampsia

questions.text: A child presents with cyanosis. His chest radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis?

Which of the following findings are seen in a high-resolution CT scan of fungal pneumonia? 1. Interlobular septations 2. Peripheral wedge-shaped consolidation 3. Pleural effusion 4. Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities
questions.explanation:
Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (ABPA)

• ABPA is a hypersensitivity reaction affecting the major upper lobe airways leading to upper lobe bronchiectasis.

• It is associated with Elevated serum IgE levels, Positive serum precipitins for Aspergillus, Respiratory symptoms similar to asthma, Skin reactivity to Aspergillus

 

Radiographic Findings:

• Non-segmental opacities primarily in the upper lobes

• Lobar collapse

• Branching thick tubular opacities due to mucus and fungus (known as the "finger-in-glove sign" or "Y" shape)

• Occasional pulmonary cavitation

Aspergillus Mycetomas/ Aspergilloma/ Fungal Ball

 

• Aspergillus mycetomas are saprophytic growths that inhabit preexisting lung cavities, 

• These are predominantly found in the upper lobes and superior segments of the lower lobes.

 

CT Characteristics:

• Appears as a mass with soft-tissue attenuation within a lung cavity.

• The mass is usually separated from the cavity wall by an airspace, known as the "Air crescent" or Monod sign.

• The position of the mass may change between prone and supine orientations, demonstrating its mobility.

Angioinvasive Aspergillosis

 

• Primarily occurs in immunocompromised individuals, 

◦ Involves invasion and blockage of small to medium pulmonary arteries.

◦ Leads to the formation of necrotic hemorrhagic nodules or infarcts.

 

CT Findings:

• Commonly presented as multiple nodules surrounded by a halo of ground-glass attenuation "halo sign" or pleural-based wedge-shaped consolidations. 

• The bronchial cut-off sign indicates central necrosis.

• Nodular opacities tend to be widespread across several lung lobes, unlike the clustered peribronchial opacities seen in bacterial infections.

questions.explanation:
Method

Principle

Measurement Basis

Key Considerations

Additional Details

Fick Principle

Oxygen uptake and arteriovenous difference

Oxygen content in blood

Accurate in steady states

Cardiac output = Oxygen Consumption / (Arterial Oxygen Content - Venous Oxygen Content)

Indicator Dilution Method

Indicator concentration dilution

Injected dye or tracer

Requires precise indicator handling

Measures dilution of an injected dye/tracer over time to calculate cardiac output.

Echocardiogram

Stroke volume estimation

Non-invasive, real-time data

Estimates stroke volume from blood velocity, multiplied by heart rate for CO calculation.

Thermodilution

Temperature change due to injected fluid

Pulmonary artery catheter insertion

Gold-standard, ideal for high cardiac output states

Measures temperature change in the pulmonary artery after injecting cold fluid.

Velocity Encoded MRI

Magnetic resonance imaging and velocity encoding

Blood flow velocity

Non-invasive, requires advanced equipment

Uses MRI to measure blood flow velocity for cardiac output estimation.

Impedance Cardiography

Electrical impedance changes

Thoracic impedance fluctuations

Sensitive to external factors

Measures electrical impedance across the thorax to calculate cardiac output.

A patient with a history of chronic alcohol use (24 units per day for the past 10 years) presents with seizures, altered mental status, auditory hallucinations, and secondary delusions. His last alcohol consumption was 2 days ago. What is the appropriate management for this patient? Diazepam Thiamine Naltrexone Flupenthixol depot injection
questions.explanation:
Alcohol Withdrawal management

Alcohol Withdrawal

Treatment

Mild or Moderate Withdrawal
  • Treatment: Benzodiazepines (e.g., lorazepam, chlordiazepoxide, diazepam).
  • Short-acting (e.g., lorazepam) or long-acting (e.g., chlordiazepoxide, diazepam).
  • Carbamazepine (daily doses of 800 mg) is also effective and has minimal abuse liability.

Severe withdrawal

(Seizures)
  • Treatment of choice: Benzodiazepines
  • Anticonvulsants are not more beneficial.

Life threatening

(Delirium Tremens)
  • For extreme symptoms (delirium tremens or DTs), Higher doses of Benzodiazepines (e.g., 50-100 mg chlordiazepoxide every 4 hours or lorazepam IV).
  • Supportive care: High-calorie diet, multivitamins.
  • Thiamine: to avoid Wernicke Encephalopathy or Korsakoff psychosis.
  • Haloperidol may be used for severe agitation but can lower the seizure threshold.

Protracted Withdrawal:

Symptoms may last 2 to 6 months.
  • Acamprosate may help diminish some symptoms.
  • Cognitive and behavioral approaches are recommended.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with schizophrenia and started on risperidone. After taking the medication last night, the patient rushed to OPD today, complaining of upward rolling of his eyes. What is the management of the condition?
questions.explanation:
Extrapyramidal Side Effects (EPS)
  • Common with first-generation antipsychotics, including symptoms like
    • Acute dystonia - Earliest, can occur within minutes of the injection
    • Parkinson's - Occurs within days to weeks
    • Akathisia - occurs within days to weeks
  • Alternatives for management include dose reduction, antiparkinson medications, or switching to medications with lower EPS risk.

Acute Dystonia

It refers to brief, sudden muscle contractions that lead to abnormal movements or postures.

Clinical manifestations
  • Oculogyric crises (upward rolling of eyes)
  • Tongue protrusion
  • Trismus (jaw muscles)
  • Torticollis (neck muscles twisting to one side)
  • Laryngospasm
  • Dysarthria, Dysphasia (glossopharyngeal symptoms)
  • Dystonic postures of the limbs and trunk.

Management
  • It can be effectively managed using anticholinergics.
  • Parenteral (IV or IM) is for immediate treatment, while oral anticholinergics are used for prophylaxis to prevent future episodes.
  • Drugs include Benztropine, Diphenhydramine, and Promethazine.

questions.text: Which statement is incorrect regarding bipolar disorder?

options.label: A
options.text: It most commonly affects ages 35-45 years

options.label: B
options.text: Type 1 is common in both sexes

options.label: C
options.text: Prevalence in the general population is 1-2%

options.label: D
options.text: Attempt to commit suicide seen in around 15% of people

questions.correct_answer: A. It most commonly affects ages 35-45 years
questions.explanation:
Bipolar disorder

Types

Bipolar I Disorder

Bipolar II Disorder

Characterized by at least 1 episode of mania and 1 episode of depression

Characterized by at least 1 episode of hypomania and 1 episode of depression

M = F (Option B ruled out)

F > M

Age of onset is between 12 - 24 years

Age of onset is slightly higher

Epidemiology
  • Annual incidence is less than 1%.
  • Depressive episodes are more common in women.
  • Women are more prone to mixed episodes and rapid cycling.
  • The prevalence rate (in the general population) of bipolar I disorder is 0 - 2.4%, and the prevalence of bipolar II disorder is 0.3 - 4.8%. (Option C ruled out)
  • Age of Onset:
    • Onset ranges from 5 to 50 years, with a mean age of 30.
    • Prevalence in adolescents rises from 2% at ages 13-14 to 4% by age 18.
  • Socioeconomic Factors:
    • Higher incidence in divorced or single individuals.
    • More common in upper socioeconomic groups and non-college graduates.
  • Suicide attempts are common in bipolar disorder, with about 15% of individuals attempting suicide at some point in their lives. (Option D ruled out)

Genetics
  • Family history increases the risk for mood disorders.
  • 1st-degree relatives have a 10-fold risk of developing bipolar disorder.
  • Genetic overlap with schizophrenia, especially on chromosomes 18q and 22q.

Brain Imaging
  • Increased hyperintensities in subcortical areas (basal ganglia, thalamus) in bipolar I disorder.
  • Imaging studies show increased dopamine transporter levels.
  • Functional imaging shows abnormal brain activation, with hyperactivity in frontal areas and hypoactivity in the amygdala and basal ganglia.

Treatment

(Options A, B & D ruled out)
  • LAMB (Liposomal Amphotericin-B) and 5-Fluorocytosine (Flucytosine) for 2 weeks
  • Fluconazole is given subsequently for 8-10 weeks.

questions.explanation:
Zone

Features

Peripheral
  • This zone makes up about 70% of the prostate gland and surrounds the urethra.
  • The majority of prostate cancers (70-80%) originate in the peripheral zone, since it is rich in glandular tissue, making it susceptible.

Central
  • It is situated at the base of the prostate gland, surrounding the ejaculatory ducts.
  • Inflammation of the prostate gland (prostatitis) commonly affects the central zone.

Transitional
  • It is located near the urethra and accounts for about 5-10% of the prostate gland.
  • BPH primarily affects the transitional zone, leading to urinary symptoms such as frequency, urgency, weak urine flow, and difficulty initiating or stopping urination.

questions.text: A patient presents with cough, cold, fever and malaise associated with weight loss and ascites. A radiograph of the chest is shown below. Ascitic fluid analysis showed elevated adenosine deaminase. Which of the following is the next step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: Start ATT after laparotomy stricture removal

questions.explanation:
Tuberculous Peritonitis

Pathophysiology
  • Results from the direct spread of tubercle bacilli from ruptured lymph nodes or intra-abdominal organs (e.g., genital TB in women), or hematogenous spread.

Symptoms
  • Abdominal: Nonspecific abdominal pain, ascites.
  • Systemic: Fever.
  • Complication: Coexistence with cirrhosis complicates diagnosis.

Diagnosis
  • Paracentesis: Reveals exudative fluid with high protein content and lymphocytic leukocytosis (neutrophils may predominate at times).
  • Direct Smear/Culture: Low yield; culturing large volumes of ascitic fluid may improve results.
  • Peritoneal Biopsy: Typically needed for diagnosis, best obtained via laparoscopy.

Treatment
  • Surgical intervention may be required for diagnosis and management in many cases.

Key features

Primary infection

Furuncle

Superficial skin infection develops in hair follicles, sebaceous gland, or sweat gland.

Carbuncle

Development of one or more abscesses in adjacent subcutaneous tissues due to the spread of infection from a furuncle.

Impetigo

The exfoliative toxin produced causes bullous impetigo, characterized by blisters.

Non-bullous impetigo is caused by streptococcus.

Acute osteomyelitis

Bacterial growth usually concentrates in a terminal blood artery of the metaphysis of a long bone, resulting in bone necrosis and persistent suppuration.

Necrotizing pneumonia
  • Caused by strains producing the PVL leukocidin.
  • Localized, destructive abscesses

Endocarditis
  • In drug addicts

Toxins mediated

Erythema and intraepidermal desquamation in neonates caused by exfoliative toxin

Toxic shock syndrome
  • TSST-1 (Toxic Shock Syndrome Toxin)
  • Early findings: Fever, vomiting, diarrhea, muscle pain
  • Later: Shock, renal, and hepatic injury, MODS
  • Tampon-associated

Staphylococcal food poisoning
  • Vomiting is prominent without fever.
  • Ingestion of enterotoxin-contaminated food causing acute vomiting and diarrhea within 1 to 5 hours of ingestion

questions.explanation:
Gastrointestinal Tuberculosis

Mechanisms of Infection
  • Swallowing of sputum with direct seeding.
  • Hematogenous spread.
  • Ingestion of contaminated bovine milk (common in developing areas).

Common sites of infection
  • Terminal ileum and cecum.

Symptoms
  • Abdominal: Pain (similar to appendicitis), swelling, obstruction, hematochezia, palpable abdominal mass.
  • Systemic: Fever, weight loss, anorexia, night sweats.
  • Complications: Ulcerations and fistulae (mimicking Crohn’s disease); anal fistula suggests rectal TB.

Diagnosis

  • Surgery is required to obtain histologic and culture specimens intraoperatively.
  • Differential Diagnosis: Difficult to distinguish from Crohn’s disease.

Tuberculous Peritonitis

Pathophysiology
  • Results from the direct spread of tubercle bacilli from ruptured lymph nodes or intra-abdominal organs (e.g., genital TB in women), or hematogenous spread.

Symptoms
  • Abdominal: Nonspecific abdominal pain, ascites.
  • Systemic: Fever.
  • Complication: Coexistence with cirrhosis complicates diagnosis.

Diagnosis
  • Paracentesis: Reveals exudative fluid with high protein content and lymphocytic leukocytosis (neutrophils may predominate at times).
  • Direct Smear/Culture: Low yield; culturing large volumes of ascitic fluid may improve results.
  • Peritoneal Biopsy: Typically needed for diagnosis, best obtained via laparoscopy.

Treatment
  • Surgical intervention may be required for diagnosis and management in many cases.

questions.text: Northern blotting is used for detection of which of the following ?
questions.explanation:
Types

Target

Features

Southern blotting

(Option A ruled out)

DNA sequences

It involves separating DNA fragments by gel electrophoresis, transferring them to a membrane, and then using labelled probes to identify specific sequences

Northern blotting

RNA sequences

(Option B)

The process is similar to DNA blotting but focuses on RNA. (Option D ruled out)

Western blotting

(Option C ruled out)

Proteins

This technique specifically detects and analyses proteins in a complex mixture. It involves separating proteins by gel electrophoresis, transferring them to a membrane, and then using specific antibodies to detect the proteins.

Eastern blotting

Post-translational modifications

It refers to specialised Western blotting techniques that detect specific post-translational modifications of proteins, such as phosphorylation or glycosylation.

Southwestern blotting

DNA-binding proteins

Combines Southern and Western blotting elements to identify proteins that bind to specific DNA sequences.

References:

6 INTERVENTIONS

6 STRATEGIES
  • Prophylactic iron-folic acid supplementation.
  • Deworming.
  • Intensified year-round behaviour change communication campaign (solid body, smart mind), including ensured delayed cord clamping.
  • Testing of anaemia using digital methods and point-of-care treatment.
  • Mandatory provision of iron folic acid fortified foods in public health programmes.
  • Addressing non-nutritional causes of anaemia in endemic pockets with a special focus on malaria, hemoglobinopathies, and fluorosis.
  • National Anaemia Mukt Bharat Unit.
  • Intra-ministerial coordination.
  • Strengthening supply chain and logistics.
  • Convergence with other ministries.
  • National Centre of Excellence and Advanced Research on Anaemia Control.
  • Anaemia Mukt Bharat dashboard and digital portal- One-stop shop for anaemia.

6 BENEFICIARIES
  • Children, 6-59 months of age (Bi-weekly Administer 1 ml of Iron and Folic Acid syrup containing 20 mg elemental iron and 100 mcg folic acid per dose)
  • Children, 5-9 years of age- pink tablets (Weekly administer one sugar-coated pink tablet of Iron and Folic Acid containing 45 mg elemental iron and 400 mcg folic acid)
  • Adolescent girls & boys (10-19 years of age)- blue tablets (Weekly administer one sugar-coated blue tablet of Iron and Folic Acid containing 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid)
  • Women of reproductive age group (20-24 years of age).(Weekly, administer one sugar-coated red tablet of Iron and Folic Acid containing 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid)
  • Pregnant women- Red tablets (180 tablets)Daily, 1 Iron and Folic Acid tablet should be taken starting from the fourth month of pregnancy (second trimester) and continued throughout the pregnancy (for at least 180 days). Each tablet contains 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid, is sugar-coated, and red in color.
  • Lactating mothers (of 0-6 months child)- Red tablets .The tablet should also be continued for 180 days post-partum. Each tablet contains 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid, is sugar-coated, and red in color.

questions.text: Which methods are used to evaluate contraceptive failure?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Reference:

Formula

(Total accidental pregnancies / Total months of exposure) x 1200

Numerator

The total number of accidental pregnancies, including pregnancies that resulted in live births, stillbirths, abortions, or are ongoing.

Denominator

(Total months in the review period) – (months stopped using contraception for non-pregnancy reasons)

Minimum Data

At least 600 months of exposure.

Disadvantages
  • PI assumes a constant failure rate over time, but contraceptive failure rates typically decline with longer use.
  • High-fertility couples conceive earlier, skewing results towards lower-fertility couples later in studies.
  • PI ignores factors beyond accidental pregnancy that affect effectiveness, like user dissatisfaction, side effects, attempts to conceive, or loss of follow-up.

Better methods

Life Table Analysis is a better method to evaluate contraceptive efficacy.

It calculates cumulative failure rates over a specified time frame, like one

month.

questions.text: Urine alkalinization will be most useful in toxicity of which of the following drugs?
questions.explanation:
Aspirin Toxicity:

Explanation
  • Aspirin stimulates the brain's respiratory center, causing hyperventilation (↓CO2 levels) and respiratory alkalosis
  • The kidneys excrete more bicarbonate to counteract respiratory alkalosis, resulting in metabolic acidosis (Compensatory metabolic acidosis). High doses of aspirin can disrupt oxidative phosphorylation and kidney function, exacerbating metabolic acidosis

Dosage and Toxicity
  • Therapeutic Dose: 3-5 g/day can cause mild chronic toxicity (salicylism)
  • Toxic Dose: Acute ingestion of 10-30 g in adults can be lethal, with much lower doses (4 mL of methyl salicylate) posing a significant risk in children

Clinical presentation
  • Salicylism: Headache, dizziness, tinnitus, reversible hearing and vision impairment, drowsiness, vomiting, hyperventilation, electrolyte imbalance
  • Severe toxicity: Dehydration, high tone deafness, confusion, petechial haemorrhages, hyperpyrexia, seizures, hypoglycemia, psychosis, coma

Management

Treatment is supportive and includes gastric lavage, correction of metabolic acidosis, vitamin K supplements and urinary alkalinization with intravenous sodium bicarbonate to enhance salicylate excretion. In severe cases, hemodialysis may be necessary.

Drug

Teratogenic Disorder

Warfarin

Fetal warfarin syndrome: Nasal hypoplasia, stippled epiphyses, limb hypoplasia, and central nervous system abnormalities.

Lithium

Ebstein's anomaly (tricuspid valve malformation).

Thalidomide

Severe limb defects (phocomelia), ear, cardiac, and genitourinary malformations.

Chloramphenicol

Gray Baby Syndrome: abdominal distension

cyanosis, respiratory distress, lethargy

Acitretin

Craniofacial anomalies, heart defects, CNS malformations.

Alcohol

Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (growth retardation, facial anomalies, CNS dysfunction, ASD, VSD).

ACE inhibitors & Angiotensin-receptor blockers

Renal dysgenesis, oligohydramnios, lung hypoplasia, skull hypoplasia.

Carbamazepine

Neural tube defects (spina bifida), craniofacial defects.

Isotretinoin

Craniofacial anomalies, heart defects, CNS malformations.

Carbimazole & methimazole

Choanal atresia, aplasia cutis, and fetal goitre.

Penicillamine

Cutis laxa syndrome.

Statins

Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheo-oesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, and limb defects (VACTERAL defects).

SSRIs

Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn.

Valproic acid

Neural tube defects (spina bifida), craniofacial defects, cardiovascular malformations, and developmental delay.

questions.text: Match the following antiarrhythmic drugs with their mechanism of action: Mechanism of action Drug Na + channel blocker K + channel blocker Na + , K + ATPase inhibitor Beta-blocker Quinidine Digoxin Esmolol Ibutilde
questions.explanation:
Drug

MOA

Quinidine

Is a Na+ channel blocker, which is a class I antiarrhythmic drug that acts by blocking sodium channels in the cardiac cells. By blocking these channels, it decreases the influx of sodium ions during the depolarization phase of the cardiac action potential.

Digoxin

It is a Na+ K+ ATPase inhibitor, which is not primarily considered an antiarrhythmic drug but rather a cardiac glycoside. However, it does have some antiarrhythmic effects. Digoxin inhibits the activity of the Na+ K+ ATPase pump, and increases intracellular calcium levels, leading to increased contractility of the heart. This indirectly helps to control certain arrhythmias, such as atrial fibrillation

Esmolol

It belongs to the class of beta-blockers, specifically a short-acting selective beta-1 adrenergic receptor blocker. It works by blocking the beta-1 adrenergic receptors in the heart, thereby reducing the effects of sympathetic stimulation.

Ibutilide

It is a potassium channel blocker, which is a class III antiarrhythmic drug that primarily blocks potassium channels in the heart. By inhibiting these channels, it prolongs the repolarization phase of the cardiac action potential, resulting in an increase in the action potential duration and effective refractory period.

Class of Drug

Mechanism of action

Sodium channel blockers (Class 1)

 

Class 1A

  • Quinidine
  • Procainamide
  • Disopyramide

Blocks sodium channels (Na+) during phase 0 of the cardiac action potential.
 

Class 1B

  • Lidocaine
  • Mexiletine

Blocks sodium channels (Na+) during phase 0 of the cardiac action potential, but with fast dissociation.
 

Class 1C

  • Flecainide
  • Propafenone

Potent sodium channel blockers (Na+) with slow dissociation from the channel.

Beta-blockers (Class 2)

  • Propranolol
  • Metoprolol
  • Esmolol
  • Carvedilol

Decrease SA and AV nodal activity by ↓ cAMP, thereby ↓ Ca currents.

Potassium channel blockers (Class 3)

  • Amiodarone
  • Ibutilide
  • Dofetilide
  • Sotalol

Delays repolarization, lengthens the cardiac action potential, and increases the refractory period.

Calcium channel blockers (Class 4)

  • Diltiazem
  • Verapamil

Reducing calcium influx during phase 2 of the cardiac action potential and decreases myocardial contractility, heart rate, and AV nodal conduction velocity.


 

Miscellaneous drugs (Class 5)

  • Atropine
  • Adenosine
  • Digoxin
  •  
  • Magnesium sulfate
  1. Atropine: DOC in bradyarrhythmias
  2. Adenosine: used in acute attacks of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia and to treat supra-ventricular tachycardia in heart failure patients
  3. Digoxin: Treat atrial flutter/fibrillation
  4. Magnesium sulfate: DOC in Torsades de pointes

questions.text: In relation to drug absorption, what does the term "extent" signify?
The image below shows the life cycle of a virus. Which of the following drugs acts at step 5?
questions.explanation:
Integrase inhibitors

MOA
  • Prevent the formation of covalent bonds between host and viral DNA
  • Inhibit the process known as strand transfer, which is a critical step in the integration of viral DNA into the host genome.

Drugs

Ends with the word -gravir: BCDER

  • Bictegravir
  • Cabotegravir
  • Dolutegravir (most used in India and safe during pregnancy)
  • Elvitegravir (used in combination with cobicistat)
  • Raltegravir

Route
  • All oral drugs except Cabotegravir (IM, once every 3 months)

Metabolism
  • CYP3A4 substrates
  • Rifampicin reduces the effect, hence increasing the dose of the integrase inhibitor

Uses
  • Treatment and post-exposure prophylaxis of HIV
  • Dolutegravir and Lamivudine: First line in treatment-naive HIV patients

Side effects
  • Rashes
  • Steven Johnson syndrome: Epidermis of the skin is damaged
  • Raltegravir: Rhabdomyolysis, DRESS
  • Bictegravir: Increase metformin concentration, hepatoxicity
  • Avoid administration with divalent cations (magnesium- or aluminium-containing antacids, iron supplements)

Type of antivirals

Mechanism of action

Examples

Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors (RTIs)

Inhibit reverse transcriptase, the enzyme that converts viral RNA into DNA

Zidovudine, Lamivudine, Tenofovir, Abacavir

Non-Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors (RTIs)

They bind directly to reverse transcriptase, blocking its ability to transcribe viral RNA into DNA.

Efavirenz, Nevirapine, Etravirine

Protease Inhibitors

Inhibit viral protease, preventing the maturation of viral proteins and the assembly of new virions.

Ritonavir, Lopinavir, Atazanavir

Integrase Inhibitors

Inhibit the integrase enzyme, preventing the integration of viral DNA into the host cell's genome.

Raltegravir, Dolutegravir, Elvitegravir

Fusion Inhibitors

Prevent the fusion of the viral envelope with the host cell membrane.

Enfuvirtide (Fuzeon), Maraviroc

Neuraminidase Inhibitors

Inhibit neuraminidase, an enzyme needed for the release of new virions from infected cells.

Oseltamivir (Tamiflu), Zanamivir

questions.text: A patient who is a known addict is brought to the hospital due to intoxication with an unknown substance. An ocular examination shows the following finding. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: This action can be reversed by phenylephrine

options.label: B
options.text: It cannot be reversed by levallorphan

options.label: C
options.text: It is caused by activation of the Edinger- Westphal nucleus

options.label: D
options.text: Tolerance develops due to long-term use

questions.correct_answer: C. It is caused by activation of the Edinger- Westphal nucleus
questions.explanation:
Opioid Overdose/ Poisoning

Management

Acute overdose/poisoning: IV Naloxone (Antidote)

↓

Maintenance (Detoxification phase: To prevent withdrawal):

  • Opioids: Buprenorphine, Methadone, Tramadol
  • Non-Opioids- Clonidine, Lofexidine

↓

Abstinence (Prevent relapse):

  • DOC: Oral Naltrexone

questions.text: A 16-year-old female presents with recent episodes of palpitations and shortness of breath. On examination, she has a systolic murmur at the cardiac apex. Laboratory evaluation shows elevated anti-streptolysin O titers and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. An echocardiogram reveals moderate regurgitation in the mitral valve. A biopsy of her heart tissue is performed, and a pathology image is provided below. Which of the following statements about this pathology is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: Present in myocardium and endocardium only

questions.correct_answer: A. Present in myocardium and endocardium only
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Present in myocardium and endocardium

Aschoff Bodies

Description

Location

  • Present in all heart layers:
  • Pericardium, Myocardium, and Endocardium

Components

  • In the center of the Aschoff nodules, fibrinoid necrosis is present
  • These are surrounded by Anitschkow cells
  • One cell has caterpillar chromatin
